title: The Sermon in the Wall
location: Temple District -> The Old Concordat Wall
description: Citizens have been reporting Concordat sermons and scripture appearing painted on Lower Ward walls overnight — identical text on different streets simultaneously, suggesting organised action. The Temple Authority wants the source identified before the situation becomes political.

turns.narrative: The painted text is precise, densely theological, and non-threatening in content — extracts from Pre-Scourge Concordat liturgy about renewal and suffering. But appearing overnight across five separate streets implies coordination, resources, and access.
turns.choice_a: Check each wall for fingerprints or physical evidence in the paint
turns.consequence_a: All walls used the same shade of deep blue paint — a specific alchemical blend that under magnification contains a mineral tracer unique to Concordat ceremonial suppliers.
turns.choice_b: Speak to residents who live closest to each wall about who they saw that night
turns.consequence_b: A resident on the third street saw three hooded figures working quickly and quietly. They moved 'like they knew exactly where they were going.'

turns.narrative: The paint traces back to a retired Concordat ceremonial supplier named Elm who now runs a small shop in the Temple District. Elm is elderly and emotional when approached — she was part of a small group of surviving Concordat faithful who believe the faith needs to be publicly visible again.
turns.choice_a: Treat this as a harmless act of religious expression and close the case
turns.consequence_a: Warden Gais is irritated but accepts. Elm's group are warned but not arrested.
turns.choice_b: Formally document the group's membership for the Temple Authority
turns.consequence_b: Warden Gais has the group registered as a recognised minority faith group — granting them limited legal protection.

turns.narrative: The walls remain painted. Warden Gais wants them erased or left as a deliberate statement.
turns.choice_a: Recommend leaving the walls as an act of faith tolerance
turns.consequence_a: Gais agrees grudgingly. The walls become something of a local landmark.
turns.choice_b: Help Elm's group repaint the walls as a proper mural with official permission
turns.consequence_b: A formal mural agreement is reached. The scripture is presented with civic pride rather than secrecy.

walls_as_landmark.description: Painted walls left as faith landmark.

official_mural.description: Walls repainted as approved civic mural.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Painted walls left as faith landmark.
